column4: I've got 3 network cards, each registered on my school's network with a static IP.  Each card is limited to 2GB up/down combined a day.  I'm looking for a way to balance my network load (primarally using bittorrent) accross all three cards.  Anyone have any ideas?
you need to turn on clustering support in the kernel, and then configure one of the clustering packages.
i assume that would require a re-compile of the kernel?  and do you have a suggestion for a clustering package?
you can also use something like traffic shaper
I've really just glanced at them.  Usually you have to rebuild the kernel, but it's possible that the distribution kernel has it as an unloaded module.
thanks, I'll take a look at what I can find
there is also support for some intelligent routing protocols.  That's another way to approach it
support in the kernel or in ubuntu in general?
the kernel.  I'm porting the kernel to a new platform so I've been into the kernel internals all day.  :)
in networking, there is support for the border gateway protocol and one or two others
sounds like loads of fun :).  I'll stick around... see what I can dig up
from what I've dug up... your suggestions for intelligent routing/cluster support require multiple machines... I'm using only one computer with 3 NICs
I know.  Let me see if I can find some docs.
much appreciated
the concept is simlar because you have more than one physical device sharing an IP address
right, but i'd be more efficient to not have my network cards talking to eachother... that would slow things down
it would be better to have a software solution, that balances the load... round robin style
yes, I know, but that way you can only balance connections, not traffic
i see... so I'm currently about to give this thing called balance a whirl (found it on sourceforge)... comments?
haven't tried it.  let me know what you find.
will do... i'm going to have to disconnect and reconnect to irc from my laptop... since i'm going to be playing with the networking on my desktop... bb in a few
